title: 103_s1899
content: No relevant information was provided in the curr_chunk and prev_chunk. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is listed on the National Historic Register and designated as a significant resource. It boasts excellent water quality, rural landscapes, historic structures, and large park areas. The Augusta Canal National Historic Landmark in Georgia features excellent water quality, rural and historic cultural landscapes, architecturally significant mill structures, national historic districts, and landmarks like Stallings Island and Meadow Garden. The Augusta Canal Area connects Laney Walker and Greene Street districts, featuring national historic landmarks like Stallings Island and Meadow Garden. The area offers undeveloped recreational opportunities and represents the development of the cotton textile industry in the South. The Augusta Canal and related mill sites represent the development of the cotton textile industry in the South, leading to the transformation of the agrarian economy into an early industrial economy. Several significant sites associated with American history are also present in the area. The Augusta Canal area in the South underwent a transformation from an agrarian economy to an early industrial economy due to the development of the canal. It is home to significant sites related to American history, including the American Revolution, Civil War, and various ethnic groups. Despite efforts by various entities, the area remains culturally, historically, and recreationally important. The Augusta Canal area, home to Americans of various ethnicities, is at risk of losing its cultural, historical, and recreational resources without Federal Government assistance. The Secretary of the Interior has designated it a priority for protection due to its threatened status. Many local, regional, and State agencies and businesses are involved in preservation efforts. The Augusta Canal area's resources are at risk without Federal Government assistance. The Secretary of the Interior has designated it a priority for protection, and there is overwhelming support from local, regional, and State agencies, businesses, and private citizens for cooperative preservation efforts. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal in Georgia to preserve its significant features while promoting economic development. The Act also defines the boundaries of the Augusta Canal National Heritage Area. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia and includes lands in Georgia and South Carolina known as the Augusta Canal. The boundaries are defined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area in Georgia and South Carolina is established, with boundaries defined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan. The Secretary of the Interior will publish a detailed description and map of the boundaries in the Federal Register. The Augusta Canal Commission is established. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including five from the Augusta Canal Authority, one from the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, and one from the Georgia congressional delegation. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed by the Secretary, including five from the Augusta Canal Authority, one from the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, one from the Georgia congressional delegation, one from the Governor of Georgia, and one from the Governor of South Carolina. The Commission elects a chairman from among its members. The Augusta Canal Commission appoints members from various entities, including the Georgia congressional delegation and the Governors of Georgia and South Carolina. The Commission elects a chairman from its members, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare and submit a management plan for the Heritage Area within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The plan should integrate Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the cultural, natural, scenic, and recreational resources of the area. The Augusta Canal Commission must prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The plan will integrate existing plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's resources. The Secretary can provide technical and financial assistance for the plan's preparation, and must approve or disapprove it within 180 days of submission. The Secretary can provide technical and financial assistance for the preparation of the management plan for the Heritage Area. Within 180 days of submission, the Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan based on criteria such as local support from various stakeholders. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan based on criteria including local support, economic impact, partnership potential, and avoiding improper infringement. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the management plan based on criteria such as local support, economic impact, partnership potential, and protection of private property rights. The Secretary will disapprove the management plan if necessary, providing reasons and recommendations for revision to the Augusta Canal Commission. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary within 180 days of receipt. The Secretary will then approve or disapprove the plan, with reasons and recommendations for revision provided if necessary. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan to the Secretary within 180 days. Upon approval, the Secretary and the Commission will implement the plan through cooperative agreements. Upon approval of the management plan, the Secretary and the Augusta Canal Commission will implement it through cooperative agreements for economic development. The Secretary can enter cooperative agreements with Georgia, political subdivisions, Augusta Canal Commission, or individuals to implement the management plan. Economic development efforts should align with the Augusta Canal Master Plan's goals. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's creation. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and the Augusta Canal Commission to ensure no adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
